SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name  ALEXANDER MAXWELL CAMPBELL
2. Your address  NEILBURG
3. Date  MARCH 17/62
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Montreal, Que
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Alex Stewart Campbell Clothing manufacturer July
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. City Montreal - built - 1904 - Alberta 1904-5
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 15 years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Weak lungs
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through a friend
1. Your full name: Alexander Maxwell

2. Your address: Neilburg

3. Date: March 17/62

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Minnedosa, Manitoba

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Alex Campbell

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): July 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Calgary, Alberta 1904-1905

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) 15 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Weak lungs

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through a friend
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Too young

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Alone

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Train to Medicine Hat Alta
   Wagon train to Macton Lake Dist. 1905

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   I traveled west on a colonist train filled with Europeans. Smell of garlic made me sick.
   I am enclosing booklet A glance back 1905-1906 written by a number of persons.
   Also a story by Miss H. A. Cogford which you may copy or return.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   In a tent

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   North of Macton Lake first
   Then moved to Claustin Alta #48

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Cancelled first homestead & moved to Claustin Alta
   30 miles away because Railway was building
   Then - came back & lost in 1919 & have
   lived here since

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   School boy
   Farming till 1941 - contractor till 1948
   M.P. 45-49-53-58 - then retired

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Twice a month or when I got a chance to get to a railway.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Married to Charlotte Graham Nov 25, 1912 - in a big house of feet - in - law south of Manton Lake - Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.
   Father came in 1910 - settled at Clavet in Alta.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Story in enclosed booklet.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Very little - all with horses.

25. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently?
   No - came permanently in 1918.

My first car in 1917

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Not until the majority had cars

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
From the beginning - no groceries - mostly clothing.

yes - mostly marriages

not very many

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I have been Secretary United Farmers - Director Telephone Co. Chairman Hospital Board. Member House Committee now of Executive director Can Mental Health Ass. Sask. Section.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I helped organize first Farmers' Edge

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Wells School was named by Mrs. Hitt (Cayford who went to a Wells School in the State of Maine U.S.A. First Post Office here named Neilburg after a first settler named O. Neil.

Wells School was named by Mrs. H.H. (Suffield) who was a Wells School in the State of Missouri. It was named after a post office named C. Neil.
